Comment: I accept this contribution, because...

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: At first I was very tempted to reject the contribution, however after seeing some of the tactics the top bots were employing (particularly in the first league of all places), I thought that there could be a lot of not only creativity but really interesting and verbose strategies that would develop over time.

After trying out all the leagues it looks like everything is in order. Overall a great concept.

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Writing a decent bot is not a trivial task

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)
Very interesting game, I Liked it.
Oh there is a comeback ?
nice
Very nice game idea !! Although it can be deduced from the grid state, it would be nice to have all mana in the inputs (both mine and opponent's)

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)

I hope we will be able to counter the full-line meta ^^" : https://www.codingame.com/replay/769048646 This could justify the implementation of points/coins or mana to set a cell to 1.

Why is the goalCell always in the same position?
Is there a particular reason why you didn't quote the rules on CodinGame?
I'd approve if I could mate, but I'm under (LVL 20)... so I can't. I like it a lot though!
When you reference goalCell in the instructions it is sometimes spelled goalCell and goalCells it can confuse some people.
You duplicated the note "NOTE: From your code's perspective". I think you should only keep one of them.

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)
In League 4 it looks like your rowCount and columnCount inputs are reversed?

I enjoyed this, but I get an error when I play League 3, and there are no battles when I try to test in the arena:

The game has crashed. Please contact the author and enclose the following error:

java.lang.RuntimeException: The amount of data sent to the viewer is too big!
	at com.codingame.gameengine.core.GameManager.dumpView(GameManager.java:294)
	at com.codingame.gameengine.core.GameManager.execute(GameManager.java:188)
	at com.codingame.gameengine.core.GameManager.execute(GameManager.java:226)
	at com.codingame.gameengine.core.AbstractPlayer.execute(AbstractPlayer.java:101)
	at com.codingame.game.Referee.gameTurn(Referee.java:265)
	at com.codingame.gameengine.core.GameManager.start(GameManager.java:122)
	at com.codingame.gameengine.core.RefereeMain.start(RefereeMain.java:67)
	at com.codingame.gameengine.core.RefereeMain.main(RefereeMain.java:50)

I like it. Some minor comments:
- For the visually impaired, add a textual desctiption of where the "green cells" are.
- "The displayed board state will be rotated 180Â° and the cell values inverted for Player 2 to maintain consistency between players.": That will be very confusing to watch and debug, especially for players that simulate the opponent. If you want to follow such an approach, perhaps it might be easier on the player to just flip the board horizontally.
Sounds great man!

Rules
* "These values represent the state of the left-most column of cells in the grid for the next turn.": Should it be left-most column for Player 1 and right-most column for Player 2?

Initial Input
* Are all the "variables" in initial input fixed? For example, rowCount and columnCount are always 32? If so, maybe this part isn't needed at all?

A better idea to me is to turn all those "variables" into true variables, i.e. rowCount and columnCount may be unequal, rowCount and columnCount aren't necessarily 32, and/or the positions of the goalCell vary from game to game.

* Please change "Lines 4 through (goalCellCount + 4)" to "Next goalCellCount lines".

* Please format the variables. See example here: https://www.codingame.com/ide/puzzle/git-patchwork and the corresponding html files here: https://static.codingame.com/servlet/fileservlet?id=104932101460256

Game Loop Input
* Please change "Lines 1 through rowCount" to "rowCount lines".

* Please change "ints"  to "integers".

* Please format -1, 1 and 0 as constants.

* Please format the variables.

Output
* Please format 1 and 0 as constants.

* Please format the variables.

* "This represents the left-most column of cells from top to bottom.": Should it be left-most column for Player 1 and right-most column for Player 2?

Constraints
* I'm not sure about what you mean by the first constraint. If the constraint is already covered by the input description, the constraint may be deleted.

Referee
* I haven't studied the referee code so I'm not sure how it handles incorrect input from players. For example, if I output some invalid input for the first turn, the viewer shows that both get 1st place, and the console is silent about the invalid output (i.e. no error messages).

Suggest to update the referee. Also suggest to add sections on Victory Conditions and Defeat Conditions (see example with linked file stated earlier), and mention what happens when a player outputs something invalid or times out (will the player fail to output always lose? or will the player who gets more points always win even if they're the one who fail to output?).

Thanks.
Looking for feedback on any and all aspects of the game (game logic, art, documentation/instructions, etc.). Thanks!

Thanks for the detailed feedback! I believe the most recent version of my game now addresses all of these points. For now I have created three leagues with different square grid sizes. I plan to add an additional league with dynamic grid aspect ratio in the future. Let me know if there is anything else that needs clarification.

Thanks for the feedback! 
- I've added some additional textual descriptions about the goal cell locations.
- I agree that it is a bit confusing but I do like the symmetry it creates. Would it be less confusing if the board was rotated so that you as the player always control the bottom row and your opponent controls the top?

Thanks for checking out the game, I'm glad you enjoyed it!

I think I've come up with a workable solution to the data limit problem... send less data! Essentially it will skip rendering some frames if too much data is getting used. Let me know what you think.
Good catch! The inputs are now fixed and the displayed grid dimensions have been flipped as well (rows x columns)
Good catch! Updated to remove the second reference.

Thanks for the feedback! The reason for the difference is that the former case refers to only a single cell (goalCell) whereas in the latter it refers to multiple cells (goalCells). Would it be more clear if only â€œgoalCellâ€ was highlighted? Or do you have any suggestions to make it easier to understand?
Thanks!

Hmm, If you mean why are the rules not displayed on this page it's because there is no place to enter them when edit the contribution ðŸ¤·â€â™‚ï¸ that might be because it's a multiplayer game instead of a CoC but I'm not sure

Yeah, I'm hoping there are counter strategies to any strategy but the full line meta seems pretty hard to beat. Adding cost is a really interesting idea! I'll play around with that.

As for goalCell position, there is no real reason it is fixed tbh. Randomizing it could be interesting

Great idea! I went ahead and added this in the latest version. Specifically, the pre-gameplay loop inputs now include the maximum mana and the gameplay loop now includes both the player and the opponent's current mana.
Oh! I saw, that you add mana ðŸ¤©
Thank you!
Thank you!
because what?
Yes.
Because what, JustForFun?
Yes, great suggestion! It balances strategies quite well. Full-line meta is no longer viable!
I mean the one on wikipedia
Ohh I understand, that's a good idea. Will do!
Updated the instructions to include the base rules
It would be better if you explain the differences in parenthesis in the beginning of the instruction.
Added some clarification around goalCells to the instructions

I don't have a strong opinion about left-right vs. top-down. I just feel like a rotation is more complicated in both settings than a simple mirroring. I'm not sure, though, if that's just me or if others feel the same.

Thank you for making the changes! The game definitely looks better now!

The only issue I can see now is that the viewer still shows Player 2 and the starting column on the right, and that's inconsistent with the statement.

(In case you don't know, you may test this out by deleting both players at the bottom of the code, then adding Boss 1 to the first slot and yourself to the second slot.)

Thanks again.

Ah, I understand the confusion. I've updated the statement to clarify the difference between what is displayed on the viewport and what the bot code receives as input. The new statement is as follows:

You control a single column on one side of the grid. Each turn, your bot will output a string of space-separated binary digits (0's and 1's).

These digits update the state of either the left or right-most columns of cells in the grid for the next turn.
- If you are Player 1, your bot's output will be applied to the left-most column (top to bottom) on the viewport grid.
- If you are Player 2, your bot's output will be flipped and applied to the right-most column (bottom to top) on the viewport grid.

NOTE: From your code's perspective, you will always control the left side of the grid regardless of whether you are Player 1 or Player 2.
The displayed board state will be rotated 180Â° and the cell values inverted before they are sent to Player 2 to maintain consistency between players.

Just asking (as I don't know whether others think the current way of displaying the board looks ok or not), would it be possible / a lot of work to change the viewer such that the board is rotated 180Â° if the player is Player 2?

That's a good question. I poked around a bit in the docs and source code for the SDK but I couldn't find any way to tell if the player is Player 1 or Player 2 so it might not be possible. If I had that info it would be a pretty trivial change!

Perhaps someone who knows the game engine better than I do would know.
Do you mean that your code is able to differentiate between Player 1 and Player 2 when accepting their inputs and updating the board, but unable to do so when drawing the board in the viewer?

Sort of. The game engine SDK gives a list of active players with consistent ordering, so Player 1 is the first player in the list and Player 2 is the second player in the list (this is the first and second slot you mentioned in a previous comment).

The difficult part is determine which slot is occupied by the Boss/Default AI and which one is occupied by player testing their code. It looks like all potentially identifying information is scrubbed before being passed to the referee game logic (e.g. the nickname and avatar are replaced with tokens like $0 and $1 which then get swapped with the real nickname/avatar in the viewer).

Oh, too bad. The viewer can cause certain confusion. Let's see what other testers/moderators think about this.

Also, it isn't necessarily the boss/default AI which may occupy one slot. Both slots may be occupied by non-boss players.

Sounds good!

> Also, it isn't necessarily the boss/default AI which may occupy one slot. Both slots may be occupied by non-boss players.

Yes, this is a good point. In the human vs. boss/default AI case it would be obvious which should be displayed on the left side. In the human vs. human case, ideally both would see their own code on the left side. Unfortunately, I am fairly certain there is no way to render the viewport differently for different players without modifying the core game engine itself to support such functionality.

The Goal (all levels)
* (just above Rules section): Change "win" to "wins".

Rules (Level 2, 3 & 4)
* "If tied, the player with the most cells occupied wins." is missing after "You win if, at the end of 200 turns, you have more points than your opponent."

Rules (Level 4)
* Please change "gridHeight" to "rowCount" for consistency (3 times). (Or the other way round, but you'll have to change, for all levels, Input section as well as the default code stub in that case.)

Game Loop Input (all levels)
* Line 2: Change "they can be use" to "they can use".

Thanks.
Fixed all of the above. Thanks!
